content:
Just letting you know that I finally added the link to your version in mine.

Also if you find some time, consider changing the /easy/ part of the link to /medium/ as suggested in the comment under @Lanfeust validation message.

And also thanks for the puzzle, it was a tough one to validate but, for whatever it's worth, I think it is great.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like how it expands upon the original "String Balls" puzzle by introducing larger radii and string lengths. By solving this extended puzzle, you can demonstrate your ability to handle more complex and computationally challenging scenarios.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like the twist regarding original problem.

I'm not sure it warrants a +2 in difficulty level, but I don't know if it is because @Rafarafa one is a bit underrated at "easy", or this one a bit overrated...

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice
i really like the idea making of more harder and complicated vers. of @Rafarafa's puzzle.

I had great pleasure solving the original puzzle from  @Rafarafa .
And I love the idea of a more complex version! But in its current form, optimization is painful, even for fast programming languages. Perhaps this is the reason for the lack of reviewers. I don't know where the reasonable limit of complexity lies. But you can consider eliminating the last few tests.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
Good
Nice one
Good

Sad to see that this found no traction. I would definitely validate if it didn't feel somewhat unfair.

But if it sits at one remaining approver I might put my morality to the side :D

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I got different results for tests "10 Char Center, Medium Radius" onwards, have you double checked them just in case?

Mine: 83023695022687
Expected: 694441526

Validator3:
Mine: 59879246589179
Expected: 246170026

Validator4:
Mine: 2142225931
Expected: 142225917
+1, Enriching.
Thank you Timinator for this game
I'm completely unbiased when I say this is a great puzzle.
Thank you! I'm going to stay in WIP for now and hope for at least one more reviewer to indicate having solved the puzzle before going to full submission.

You are missing one key part of the puzzle. Read through the directions and I think you'll see what you missed. Great job so far though. All the answers you're getting are on the right track to getting the correct final answers.

Another new "upvote" today. Over the past several months, it seems that reviewers are somewhat hard to come by, especially on classic puzzles.

I'm working on a Machine Learning model to predict the sentiment of Codingame reviewers. I will share via PM when I have a model that seems capable of predicting this seemingly random phenomenon.

I really appreciate your feedback. Let me know your thoughts after I share the following:

1) The puzzle has two keys that must be figured out for ultimate success - First, optimizing speed via some sort of Dynamic Programming. Second - thinking outside the box to come up with an overall approach to the problem that handles small test cases as well as large test cases.

2) I didn't want to make the test cases so extreme, but to make the puzzle the same for all languages I had to do it. You might wonder what language caused me the problems, right? Believe it or not, it was Python.

Python is given a very generous time limit for puzzles. By using numpy (which is written in C and C++), my first edition of this puzzle could be solved in Python by only addressing the first point above. By using numpy, you can get all the speed of C/C++, but still enjoy Python's generous time limit. As far as I know, all other languages would need to figure out both things above. I did code a solution in C and I could not solve the puzzle within the CG time limit for C if only #1 above was addressed.

I  think (and I believe @Rafarafa agrees) the solution to this puzzle is really cool and wonderfully satisfying when you figure it out. Without the extreme cases, it is possible (I believe probable) for Python programmers to cut and past (with minor modifications) the numpy solution that works so elegantly on the original String Balls.

So...for the puzzle to exist and meet the design objectives in all languages, the extreme test cases must remain.

I agree with you. I think this puzzle is on par with @java_coffee_cup's Cylinders, which I thought was pretty hard for "medium". Obviously, difficulty level is very subjective and sometimes having only three categories really complicates the challenge of proper placement.

Either way I go, I believe some folks will disagree. In the end, a medium puzzle will most likely attract more puzzlers than a hard puzzle.

Puzzle changed to medium.

Iâ€™m away from my computer, but I will make the update this afternoon. Thank you for your support and comments. Iâ€™m getting old and my memory fades quickly. I can no longer remember the details of our conversations that eventually resulted in this puzzle. I just remember the process was super fun and I very much appreciate your willingness to engage. You are a tremendous asset to the Codingame community!

Mm, looking at my contrib I changed the difficulty back to medium quite soon after its validation (it has been medium for 5 months), and it sits at 50% success rate so I guess it was a good change?

Source, first comment here:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/388573d78acaeca9e34861401284ecfbe5447

CG itself tags dynamic programing as hard (assuming that the gold color means that). Having just witnessed yesterday how many of my friends gave up on the AoC puzzle because it required dynamic programming makes me thing they are right.

(And the first version of String Balls needed none of that. My published solution is some recursion with no cache whatsoever, and the tests were made with that in mind)

At least, I can speak for myself in that this version entailed a huge gap in difficulty compared to the first one, and that I would find odd them being assessed as "equally difficult" (even if I know that this is not what being in the same category means).

Edit: But as you can tell, I'm usually wrong in these matters, and I will probably validate it anyway before the reset if no one else does.

Edit2: it's @rafarafa, @rafa was taken so it became @rafa * 2

My bad, I just looked at the url, didn't check the actual current level.

Original at medium and this one at hard is consistent.

And indeed, yesterday's AoC allowed me to snatch my first win in our group :-) (there are a couple of furious guys who wake up at a time that is completely unthinkable for me !)
Great points @Rafarafa. You both finished cylinders.  is this puzzle harder than that? Maybe I just struggled a bunch on that puzzle.

Well, Cylinders is a bit controversial... It can be brute-forced with fast languages, but my Python code needed more. It stays simpler (at least shorter) than what I did here, but unfortunately, as it was pointed out to me, it is incorrect (obviously without any test case exhibiting the problematic edge-case)...
In the discussion, I said :
> And this goes some way into thinking that this is more of a Hard problem, when you need somewhat tricky optimizations to pass with slow languages.

So all in all, I'll stick with Hard for this one.
And anyway, it is always somewhat subjective, so it seems normal to have quite a bit of fuzziness in the limit between difficulty levels.

Fuzziness indeed. 

Changed back to hard.

It got validated, hurrah!

I think the cylinder's one was easier to me. It seems to sit at 20% success rate so maybe there is an argument for it to be hard but oh well. It could have been luck, something could have clicked faster, I don't know. 

I also spent quite some time in the first verstion of this puzzle, plus the discussion that we had back then. I can't be objective.

I think what @Lanfeust was refering is that the link in the statement:

https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/string-balls

while valid (since the puzzle was indeed validated easy), is not longer up to date and should be:

https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/string-balls

I will also add a link to part2 in the description of part1 tomorrow. I'm a bit tired now.

Edit: since the links are trimmed by CG, I meant to replace "easy" with "medium" in the link.
Detailed answer, thanks. I don't use Python, so I won't say anything about Numpy. Otherwise, you may be right, the puzzle is marked as hard. This means you need to put more effort into solving it.
omg I'm dumb...
ðŸ˜€ it doesnâ€™t feel right to upvote that comment, so you get a smiley instead!
I solved it
New test cases have been added to increase the difficulty.
Narrative and constraints have been updated to properly align with new test cases from 10 days ago.

Constraints section
* Please change "< 5000" to "<= 5000" (the length of center in the last test "Please Stop!" is exactly 5000).

* Suggest to delete the third constraint as it is implied from the last sentence of Goal section and it doesn't really restrict the scope of the cases (and hence it isn't really a "constraint").

* Note: Suggest to delete the first sentence, and change "because they are known" to "and guaranteed".

Cases
* The first Validator 11 should be renamed as Validator 9.

Thanks.
Done Thank you!
